en: Don Quixote and Sancho in search of adventures / Scrutiny of don Quixote's library

In the upper half, a canonical image of don Quixote on Rocinante accompanied by Sancho on his donkey surrounded by an ornamental frame with images of Dulcinea, castles, damsels, errant knights, enchanters, dragons, armies...In the lower half, the scrutiny of don Quixote's library (with the housekeeper, the niece, the priest and the barber; as carved in a pedestal), Cervantes' portrait, arms, a barber basin and a sand clock.Illustration with combination of fantasy and reality in keeping with the romantic tradition.Remarkable drawing and engraving.
32.2 The Duke gives SP the governorship of insula Barataria

Sancho, by order of don Quixote, kneels before the Duke and the Duchess to thank them for the governorship of Barataria Island.In the background, the angry ecclesiastic.Title and scene are integrated in an architectural structure.Remarkable drawing and engraving; simple but original composition.
Don Quixote encounters two party girls
2.2. DQ arrives at inn (castle)2.3. DQ received by ”ladies”

Gilbert has chosen an instant of the chapter more comical for the dialogue (see their gestures and expressions) than for the action.Remarkable drawing, quite picturesque (architecture, both women...), and engraving.
Don Quixote knighted by the innkeeper
3.4 DQ knighted at inn by innkeeper

Simple composition; don Quixote knelt before the innkeeper, who holds a sword and a book; witnessing the scene, a boy holding a candle and two party girls (doña Tolosa and doña Molinera); figures accurate to Cervantes' text.Good light and shadow effects.Remarkable drawing and engraving.
Don Quixote and the Basque lady

The Basque lady, accompanied by one of her damsels and other companion, all knelt, begs don Quixote not to hurt her squire (lying defeated and half-dead in the background).Don Quixote's figure is victorious and clement; see his gesture.Remarkable drawing and engraving; notice some excellent details, such as the lady's dress, shading...

In the foreground, Sancho being blanketed in the courtyard of Juan Palomeque's inn; don Quixote observes the scene, unable to help his squire, from behind the inn wall.Well-known scene and composition, with little novelty.Remarkable drawing and engraving; notice the faces and expressions of the men, some of them are excellent caricatures; one is looking at the viewer directly.

In Sierra Morena, Princess Micomicona (Dorotea) kneels before don Quixote begging for his help; also in the scene, Sancho and the barber (disguised with a fake beard, although he looks like a real old man).Remarkable drawing and engraving; notice the use of white and black contrasts; skilful drawing without too many details.Micomicona's figure, of great beauty, is especially remarkable too.

In the foreground, don Quixote attacking the wineskins; accurate to Cervantes' text, asleep, with a night cap on his head, a blanket wrapped around his arm and brandishing his sword.The innkeeper, followed by the priest, the barber, Dorotea and others, enters the room to stop him.Notice the remarkable use of light and shadow; don Quixote appears well-lighted while the innkeeper, the other figures and the room are darker.Remarkable drawing and engraving and well-resolved movement.
Don Quixote's fight with a penitent

Remarkable figures resolved with opposite and good movements; both with great force too.The figure of the penitent, with his back turned to the viewer, is specially remarkable.Notice don Quixote's face and expression (mad eyes).
Don Quixote arrives to his village enchanted in a cage on an oxcart
52.3 Arrival of DQ and Sancho to their village

The housekeeper and the niece receive don Quixote, who arrives "enchanted" in a cage on an oxcart.The faces of the three main characters (housekeeper, niece and don Quixote) are very remarkable.Picturesque setting.Excellent drawing and engraving.

1 - Ashbee reads the engraver's signature as "Blauer", but neither "Blauer" or "Slaver" are known engravers. Other illustration (DQ, Montesinos and Durandarte; f.p. 329) is signed by "S. SLV", signature that could refer to the same engraver (Slaver?) of the current illustration.
Don Quixote and the enchanted Dulcinea
10.2 The three labradoras10.3 SP presents to DQ the enchanted Dulcinea

Don Quixote and Sancho kneel before three peasant girls on donkeys while the squire introduces one of the peasant girls to don Quixote as the "enchanted" Dulcinea.Good drawing and engraving, although in some details (see the girls' faces) the drawing style is very free.Don Quixote's figure is remarkable.
